verses.verse: I have taken the Levites instead of all the firstborn of the children of Israel.

And (Num. 3:9) I have given the Levites as a gift to Aaron and his sons from among the children of Israel, to do the work for the children of Israel in the tabernacle of meeting, and to make atonement for the children of Israel, (Num. 1:53; 16:46; 18:5; 2 Chr. 26:16) that there be no plague among the children of Israel when the children of Israel come near the sanctuary.”

Thus Moses and Aaron and all the congregation of the children of Israel did to the Levites; according to all that the LORD commanded Moses concerning the Levites, so the children of Israel did to them.
(Num. 8:7) And the Levites purified themselves and washed their clothes; then Aaron presented them like a wave offering before the LORD, and Aaron made atonement for them to cleanse them.
(Num. 8:15) After that the Levites went in to do their work in the tabernacle of meeting before Aaron and his sons; (Num. 8:5) as the LORD commanded Moses concerning the Levites, so they did to them.
Then the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
“This is what pertains to the Levites: (Num. 4:3; 1 Chr. 23:3, 24, 27) From twenty-five years old and above one may enter to perform service in the work of the tabernacle of meeting;
and at the age of fifty years they must cease performing this work, and shall work no more.
They may minister with their brethren in the tabernacle of meeting, (Num. 1:53) to attend to needs, but they themselves shall do no work. Thus you shall do to the Levites regarding their duties.”
The Second Passover Now the LORD spoke to Moses in the Wilderness of Sinai, in the first month of the second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt, saying:
“Let the children of Israel keep (Ex. 12:1-16; Lev. 23:5; Num. 28:16; Deut. 16:1, 2) the Passover at its appointed (2 Chr. 30:1-15; Luke 22:7; (1 Cor. 5:7, 8)) time.
On the fourteenth day of this month, at twilight, you shall keep it at its appointed time. According to all its rites and ceremonies you shall keep it.”
So Moses told the children of Israel that they should keep the Passover.

And (Josh. 5:10) they kept the Passover on the fourteenth day of the first month, at twilight, in the Wilderness of Sinai; according to all that the LORD commanded Moses, so the children of Israel did.

Now there were certain men who were (Num. 5:2; 19:11-22; John 18:28) defiled by a human corpse, so that they could not keep the Passover on that day; (Ex. 18:15, 19, 26; Num. 27:2) and they came before Moses and Aaron that day.
And those men said to him, “We became defiled by a human corpse. Why are we kept from presenting the offering of the LORD at its appointed time among the children of Israel?”
And Moses said to them, “Stand still, that (Ex. 18:22; Num. 27:5) I may hear what the LORD will command concerning you.”
Then the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
“Speak to the children of Israel, saying: ‘If anyone of you or your posterity is unclean because of a corpse, or is far away on a journey, he may still keep the LORD’s Passover.
On (2 Chr. 30:2, 15) the fourteenth day of the second month, at twilight, they may keep it. They shall (Ex. 12:8) eat it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
(Ex. 12:10) They shall leave none of it until morning, (Ex. 12:46; (John 19:36)) nor break one of its bones. (Ex. 12:43) According to all the ordinances of the Passover they shall keep it.

But the man who is clean and is not on a journey, and ceases to keep the Passover, that same person (Gen. 17:14; Ex. 12:15, 47) shall be cut off from among his people, because he (Num. 9:7) did not bring the offering of the LORD at its appointed time; that man shall (Num. 5:31) bear his sin.

‘And if a stranger dwells among you, and would keep the LORD’s Passover, he must do so according to the rite of the Passover and according to its ceremony; (Ex. 12:49; Lev. 24:22; Num. 15:15, 16, 29) you shall have one ordinance, both for the stranger and the native of the land.’ ”
